video.title: AWS Certified Solutions Architect - Associate 2020 (PASS THE EXAM!)
video.description:
AWS Certified Solutions Architect is one of the most popular cloud computing certifications. In this full course taught by an expert trainer, you will learn the major parts of Amazon Web Services, and prepare for the associate-level AWS Certified Solutions Architect exam. By the end of this course, you will be ready to take the AWS Certified Solutions Architect Associate exam - and pass!

🎥 Course developed by Andrew Brown of ExamPro. Check out the ExamPro YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2EsmbKnDNE7y1N3nZYCuGw
🔗 ExamPro AWS Obsessed Certification Training: https://www.exampro.co
🔗 LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/exam...
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/examproco
📷 Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/exampro.co/

⭐Course Contents⭐
Check the pinned comment for the course contents with time codes. This course is so massive the full contents won't fit in this description!

⭐️ More AWS Courses ⭐️
🎥 AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner Training: https://youtu.be/3hLmDS179YE
🎥 AWS Certified Developer Associate Training: https://youtu.be/RrKRN9zRBWs
🎥 AWS for Startups - Deploying with AWS: https://youtu.be/U3VSJhaC4kc

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

@Thanos Bhau Incredible offer 50% on Exam Test for AWS Certified Solutions Architect (Associate)/ Mock Test for next 5 days. So Hurry up and avail this offer. 
This AWS practice quiz consists of 65 questions with a mix of questions on core AWS services, including all services which are at the AWS Architect (Associate) level. Please note that, unlike the real AWS Certified Solutions Architect (Associate), so you can take as much time as required to answer each question. At the end of the test, you get to review your answers and find detailed explanations of why each answer is wrong or right along with reference links for each question. This will help you identify your strength and weaknesses. With these popular Practice Tests, you’ll know when you are ready to pass your AWS Certified Solutions Architect (Associate)/ AWS Solution Architecture Certification.

topLevelComment.author: zaki abouchi
topLevelComment.text:
NACL is stateless, meaning any change applied to an incoming rule isn’t automatically applied to an outgoing rule.
SG is stateful, which means any changes which are applied to an incoming rule is automatically applied to a rule which is outgoing.

I have a question regarding VPCs. 
.
If I have a internet gateway associated with my main route table of VPC and I have a private subnet. Will the resources in private subnet able to access internet due to the IGW? 
.
If yes then, why do we enable auto assign public IP in the subnet as we already have internet access.

replies.author: Prabhjit Bagga
replies.text: I believe the answer is yes. For every subnet that you need internet access to, you will need to have a default route pointing to the IGW. The "assign public IP in the subnet " just allows for a public IP to be associated with the Instance. It will not be accessible until the route to igw exists.

topLevelComment.author: SkyFlex
topLevelComment.text:
I passed my exam today! I studied 1-2 hours every day for 4/5 weeks then took a week off work to bulk prepare the week leading to the exam. I see comments asking if this course is still applicable, below is my two cents:

Short Answer: Yes but not exclusively.  Use in conjunction with other resources.
Long Answer: I would say this does cover some core foundational knowledge, but due to its age it is missing some focus on other/new services. I would use this as your foundational knowledge to get a high level (and some low level) on the main services, but you will certainly not pass if you use this exclusively. Personally I used this in conjunction with Pluralsight (like Linkdin Learning, did the 12-hour Architect Associate Path), many test papers, AWS Learning resources and their documentation. Obviously everyone doesn't get the same test, but here's some details around mine

No questions related to DynamoDB 
No questions on DR (Pilot Light, Warm Standby, etc)
No questions on EC2 types like when to choose Compute Optimised, etc
2 Questions on AWS Organizations and SCPs (Service Control Policies) - this is not on this course and would have gotten me but I have extensive on-job experience with these. 
            - Ensure you cover Organizations at the high level, such as OUs and SCPs. SCPs have some key differences VS normal IAM policies.

2/3 Questions on EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service) - nothing 'Kubernetes-specific' but more about the service and CloudWatch Integration (Container Insights) - again not on this course and I have personal experience which got me through that questions

More questions than I was expecting on Windows-specific storage options. Make sure you know when to use a given service for windows or not - including FSx

Few questions on analysing policies, picking the right one based on scenario given. Permission Boundary came up too.
Few questions on IAM in general 
Plenty of questions on Autoscaling
Lots of questions on EBS, EFS - when to choose one or the other. I would say I got 6-8 questions across all 'topics' on these and details in some of these questions where not covered via this and require more detail knowledge.
Only one question on EBS Storage types.
Plenty of questions on S3 and a few on SnowBall. 
Plenty of Questions on Aurora, RDS - these for me where some of the most difficult. Would recommend diving deep on Aurora more than what this course does. 
More questions than I was expecting around VPN, Direct Connect, Private Link, Endpoints & Hybrid cloud options - these where also difficult for me
Few questions on Storage gateway which I found challenging 
Few questions on KMS in general and when to use in each service VS service-native encryption for given scenario
Few questions on Redshift but mostly picking no because questions related on 'Cost effective' solution for given scenario - which Redshift often wasn't for scenario given.
Few questions on Kenisis - these where likely the ones I got mostly wrong as its a harder service to have experience with.

A big thanks for this tutorial Andrew Brown. I just cleared SAA within a week. Two Certifications in two weeks using your free videos. This is great public service you have done by bringing these free tutorials.  Some advice to people who are planning to take SAA: 
Try to consume all the question resources free ones and paid ones too.  I took Whizz labs paid practice test - but the exam was more difficult then whizz labs tests even. Try to write down the things which are new in the Mock tests which are not covered by Andrew Brown. I had zero previous AWS experience except the CCP  exam which I passed a week ago from Andrew Browns video. In addition, Andrew browns videos might not be enough resource, try to consume every free resource in YouTube. I was working with these videos 12-14 hours a day writing everything down (maybe that's why it took me so much hours per day), but you don't have to target it in one week. topLevelComment.author: ali
topLevelComment.text:
I think there's a mistake 1:33:08
NACLs - used for subnet level control - do not care about the state, and thus, have both inbound and outbound rules. by default, they are configured to allow all traffic at ingress and egress. as NACLs are stateless, if you wish to deny traffic at the NACL layer, you must explicitly define filters in both the inbound and outbound rules.

It should be if traffic is allowed inbound, it'll not necessarily be allowed outbound, it'll also follow the rules of the NACLs.

Thanks for the great resource

topLevelComment.author: Simon Edwards
topLevelComment.text:
I passed the AWS Solutions Architect Associate exam yesterday and just wanted to say thanks for uploading this course. It was a great source of revision and really help me prepare of the exam.

One big tip I'll give for people planning to this this exam, the questions are nearly all scenario based. Do at least 1 practise exam to get used to how the questions are presented. Once you have read a few, you get a feel for them and they almost seen to follow the same pattern. The answer can often obvious, once you read the question and properly. It's all about understanding what they're asking for, pay attention to key words that will give you clues.

replies.author: Leslie Ren
replies.text: @Yuri Hi Terry, the contents from the actual exam I took were mostly covered by this video.  I would say somewhere around 90-95%.  The rest were questions on other AWS services.  I had a few Qs on AWS WAF, CloudHSM and a few really niche ones (Personally I think they were test questions and did not count towards the final score but I wouldn't know for sure).  However, I have come across some of them in the practice exam I have mentioned above.  IMO, if you study this video and the practice exam (including the detailed explanation and answers) by either John or Neal, you should be able to pass the exam.  The exam I did focused heavily on SQS, SNS, RDS, Multi AZ deployment if memory serves correct.  Good luck with your study!

topLevelComment.author: vishwas gautam
topLevelComment.text:
1:33:23 I think this needs to be corrected as NACL require explicit outbound rules.
  Network ACLs are stateless, which means that responses to allowed inbound traffic are subject to the rules for outbound traffic (and vice versa).

topLevelComment.author: Ben Burdick
topLevelComment.text:
Noticed that at 1:33:20, you say that NACLs are STATELESS, which is true. But then you say that STATELESS means "any allowed inbound traffic is also allowed outbound", which is NOT true. 

STATELESS means that the request and response are not tracked, so you need to explicitly allow INBOUND and OUTBOUND traffic if you need that.

replies.author: Bharadwaj Sangaraju
replies.text:
I think you need to explicitly DENY for NACLs, not ALLOW. For Security Groups, it's the other way around.
Please correct me if I'm wrong. 🙏

replies.author: Stanley Ochiobi
replies.text:
For most part I used this video, watched a coupled of more videos on Amazon website on different services to get a deeper understanding. In addition, I also viewed a number well-architected framework videos on YouTube(since I could not read the documentation). 

You have to understand the services (including some not mentioned here such as Fargate, Global Accelerator, ECS...). You should understand how the different services come together to meet the requirements for a well-architected framework as the questions are mainly on used cases for this. And lastly, look at some past questions and verify your answers as well on those past question sites (check exammtopics.com).

In all, please study as non or only few of the past questions you find on these sites might not come up as in my case. Best of luck

topLevelComment.author: jGarvey Analytics
topLevelComment.text: Passed the exam today. The material in this video is very useful but the exam is not as easy as some people in the comments are making it out to be. Of course, as always, supplement your learning with additional resources. This video is invaluable and we are grateful to the content creator. However there is a difference between cramming a video for a certification and actually spending a few weeks or months trying out the functionality on a test account. This video is really really good and it covers most of it not all the topics in substantial detail. But again, there will be questions in the exam that are in some way related to this content but would have required you to understand it from a solution architect’s perspective, not just by remembering cheat sheets and slides. You need to know how different services integrate with each other and be careful reading the questions. The most cost effective solution may not be the best solution for performance or HA. And so on...

replies.author: Philip J. Reed

For example, 2 of the 25 questions were about AWS Organizations, which I'd not heard of. To be fair I've skipped over some parts of the video to come back later.

I agree with your comments -- this video is an incredible resource. Did you find there were AWS services not covered that were important on your exam? 

Also I like your note that this video is about the building blocks, whereas the exam is about integration across many services.

topLevelComment.author: Robert Molina
topLevelComment.text: Thanks Andrew Brown.  I was able to barely pass the test with your video along with the skillcert pro recommendation other folks have done here for practice.  I constantly rewatched the videos and did some of the follow alongs such as s3.  I definitely ended up reading the AWS docs to follow up after doing the exams on skillcert pro.  I did about 8 exams from skillcert.  In the practice exams  I scored around 28% after only watching 3 hours.  Then  61% after going through the whole video (about a full week). Then 77% after a few days of reviewing material again and going over the questions I missed in previous exams.  Then 69%, 65%, 72%,  and finally 86%.   I worked with a study group as well for about 3 days about an hour and half each day just to verbally discuss the concepts and topics I felt unsure about since I seem to learn better in engaged conversations vs simply watching videos and reading up on my own. In total I spent around 2 and a half weeks to prepare.  I do have a technical background and discuss it at a more high level the past 5-6 years, so watching the video Andrew provided really excelled my review and learning of the concepts in more detail.  For instance, I heard of S3, auto scaling groups, but how it worked and specific nuances of those services I wasn't aware of and had to learn.   I took the exam at a site in Santa Clara California via PSI.  Lastly, just wanted to say the skillcert pro can improve on its quality (misspelled words, there was one question where part of the question sentence was accidentally included in the answer, guess someone tired of copying and pasting).  Also, they can try to rephrase some of the questions so one doesn't get use to memorizing answers for questions but rather read into the concepts. Hopefully that helps everyone, I just wanted to provide  my feedback since I learned a lot from you all that posted.

topLevelComment.author: Sulogna Ruby Saha
topLevelComment.text:
I’m so glad I found this. It indeed took a lot of effort to build this and I really appreciate all your work @Andrew. It’s so nice to read all the positive comments. I just finished my exam today and I passed 🙃 I studied for less than a month tbh. I found this video two days back and I am glad I did. I rushed through X1.75 but it did definitely help me a lot. 
Here's my two cents to whoever needs it.
The questions I got were mainly related to :
ASG and ELBs
few questions on how to build your secure VPCs, 
security groups/nacls, 
ec2,ebs cost optimization, 
how to make your application HA and scalable in terms of DBs and computes 
2 or 3 questions where I had to choose between databases, 
one question where I had to choose between messaging services (message broker - MQ), 
2 questions where I had to choose between storages - where the answer was mainly (EFS),
1 question where I had to decide on what aws service to use to deploy my application to AWS
Obviously had 2 questions to choose between gp2 io1 st1 sc1 to confuse they had added instance store SSD too,
1 question on how you would share your content in a particular region where the traffic is more. Most of the times they trick you to choose CloudFront (*Remember : CloudFront is for S3 only)
1 question on CloudFormation template : What is the mandate security measure that you need to take. (so VPC - Cloud Formation)

topLevelComment.text: I passed the SAA-C01 but not just with this. This was where I learned the majority of what I needed to know though. And I made flash cards from another site that I can’t remember that had practice test questions. I started with no knowledge of AWS on April 14th and passed yesterday. I failed my first time taking my exam so do not get discouraged. Lastly I watched the curriculum video for the Solutions Architect Associate provided on AWS-very helpful and has tips for getting correct answers. In total spent approximately $450 between exam costs, practice tests, and printing costs to get this certification. This video is amazing for getting the ground work placed for passing the Cert exam.

topLevelComment.author: Sujay
topLevelComment.text:
I just cleared the SAA-02. A few observations :
1. There was quite a bit of emphasis on hybrid cloud ( questions on private gateways, EFS, windows file systems service, etc)
2.  High Availability Architecture : you should be comfortable with these kind of questions.  
3.  Taking practice tests from Linux Academy and Udemy helped. It gives you practice on time management, familiarity with HA / Fault tolerant kind of questions and also hybrid cloud kind of questions. Helps you with your timing also
4.. Read the suggested Amazon FAQ's. Create your own cheat sheets for them as well
5.  Take the free digital course offered by AWS. It helps as well.  Gives you a fair idea on the process of elimination. 

I'd like to thank freeCodeCamp. This video was very very helpful. 
Good luck to everyone taking this :)

topLevelComment.author: Jeff
topLevelComment.text: Network ACLs are stateless, which means that responses to allowed inbound traffic are subject to the rules for outbound traffic (and vice versa). NACL Cheat sheet is wrong definition of stateless, you must allow the traffic in the other direction, it will not allow a response unless you do.

topLevelComment.author: cmann
topLevelComment.text:
Took the exam today and did not pass, I used this as a resource and acloud guru, as well as practice exams from Udemy. I rate this content, however, it really seems to be dependant on the type of questions you are provided, my exam had more questions than i was used to on Encrption, containers (Docker), HA architecture, Load balancers, DBs, a few on VPCs (which was surprising as i am used to a lot more) and elasticache with reddis (these are what i remember). 


I have done some research and found that some people had a similar experience as me. whereas some people have got by just on video course content and the cheat sheets or the summary slides from acloud guru (this would not be sufficient for what i had today). Have to wait two weeks to take again but i would highly recommend buying or taking some official exams, as although i had an understanding of the concepts asked, the material i used did not go into enough depth for the questions. 


I would look at white papers and the FAQ's on the amazon website for any material you come across in the practice papers that gives you a similar problem. As i say, i rate this content and the instructor, very valuable resource. Just wanted to give anyone a heads up and hope this advice helps others.

topLevelComment.author: Pete Miller
topLevelComment.text: Andrew, just a suggestion:  NEVER EVER put in *.domainname.TLD.  Use of * (wildcard) in SSL/TLS certificates is NOT a 'Best Practice' and can be a security vulnerability finding.  Best to plan out what your use-case(s) will be and use SAN (Subject Alternative Name) entries with your SSL/TLS certs, to cover the use-case(s).   (I have 15+ years of Enterprise PKI experience and can say that I've had numerous instances where certificate requesters used a Wildcard and at some point later (days or weeks) ended up with vulnerability findings and/or issues with various browsers accepting the wildcard.
